nodes.bodyText:
As a general observation, always think twice about what tree is reported, it will define what is highlighted in the different products, if the tree is too big, it will result in something ugly.
This is especially true for method invocation: arguments can be unusually long, a huge lambda, or a huge message for example!
Since the actual code is reporting on the literal, I believe we should keep this behavior in order to avoid having issues changing line.
You can eventually add a secondary location (see #2915 for an example of secondary) to the method identifier to make it clearer! (you can use ExpressionUtils::methodName for this).
I believe you can remove (or extract it for later use) this matcher, it is not useful anymore and you will be able to avoid the check at line 94.
You can use the matcher at line 55 (extracted from the others) to get the same behavior. You can use .addParametersMatcher(MethodMatchers.ANY) in order to be sure that we have one argument.

beforeCommit.message:
Make issues only appear on the method name and the literals

Also refactor the code a bit, so there are only two calls to
reportIssue - one for each message type. That way the code to
find the secondary locations to mark doesn't have to be repeated
in multiple places.

nodes.bodyText:
You can test the secondary location position with [[sc=22;ec=32;secondary=21]].
You have to use line numbers, so in practice, each time you add a new line above, you will have to update it. This can be annoying, I therefore try to have only a few examples testing secondary location at the beginning,

It's confusing that findLiterals returns a list of ExpressionTree and not LiteralTree.
Similarly at line 157 checkEqualityAssertWithOneLiteral has an argument named ExpressionTree literal, while it can be something else than a literal (a typecast).
Why not working with LiteralTree everywhere instead (extracting the literal from the cast)?
(it could also enable you to avoid a second call to isNullLiteral at line 159)
Not sure this message suits well all the situations in which it will be displayed! Why not something more generic, an idea could be:  There's no reason to use this literal value here.

Same here concerning the message, while the message totally makes sense for the main location (highlight the method name and advise to use another one), I'm not sure it makes sense for the secondary location.
You can extract this call in order to not call it twice with the same argument.

The method ordering looks strange to me, I would rather go for:

checkEqualityAsserts
findLiterals
reportDefaultMessage

I may be biased by personal opinion, but it seems to be the commonly agreed convention used in our Java projects.
Is there any particular reason to use this instead of .collect(Collectors.toList()); ?

commit.message:
SONARJAVA-3350 S2701: support null literal

Make the rule S2701 report issues on null literals as well as Boolean
literals. Also improve the message when a null or Boolean literal is
used with assertEquals and similar methods.
Extract the method matcher for assertThat

Make issues only appear on the method name and the literals

Also refactor the code a bit, so there are only two calls to
reportIssue - one for each message type. That way the code to
find the secondary locations to mark doesn't have to be repeated
in multiple places.
Return optional literals instead of checking literalness
